> [shift](#comment_2_16AFTG7vdicwJbRQpWc2F9BRHTE5MTftE7): 

Probably easier to write it in a cross platform language that compiles to Objective-C and Java so the core only has to be written once to support both iOS and Android natively. Otherwise it's just too much work for a small team, at that point you'd have to keep three separate implementations updated (Python, Swift, Java). Then you could even scrap the Python version and just use that cross platform language for Win/Mac/Linux/iOS/Android, all native.

Is Swift usable yet? When it was first released and Apple said it's so darn fast, I remember seeing a few companies write angry articles a month or two later saying Apple lied and it's multiple times slower than Objective-C (I think it was 5 to 15 times slower depending on what you're doing) so they had to scrap all their Swift work and go back to Objective-C because Swift was just way too slow for them (still a lot faster than interpreted languages of course).

> [nippletwister](#comment_7_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf): Amazing work! Is it possible to use the same tasks list on PC and mobile?

Thanks! :)

Your todos you should be able to access from any computer where you copied your user information to. I've never tried this but I believe you just have to copy the YourZeroNetFolder/data/users.json file over to the other computer. Maybe also the sites.json file in the same directory, that I am not sure about, but the information should be easy to find on ZeroTalk and maybe you already know about that.

If you make a change on one computer and you have the site opened on both, you will even see the other update live as you make changes (unless there are unsaved changes on the other computer, then it ignores them so your changes aren't lost and you can decide what to do).

But as far as I know, the way most people use ZeroNet on mobile right now is by using a proxy like bit.no.com:43110. You obviously should not use your main user data there, you'd give your private key (which is also used for the encryption) over to a third party and that isn't safe. So an alternative if you do want to use a proxy would be to create an account on that proxy and use that proxy on both mobile and PC whenever you want to access your todos. Then if it turns out the proxy is malicious or was hacked or whatever, only your todos are compromised, not your whole main ZeroNet account.

Much safer though would be if you run your own server or if your home computer is on all the time so you can use that as the server, or maybe a Raspberry Pi or something like that which doesn't drain much power. Or if ZeroNet adds official support for mobile so you can install the client on your phone, which I assume will be the case at some point in the future :)

> [gomzik](#comment_2_1F6BMqittjWUStzUbRXm2kG2GQ3RdBLqFQ): So, do you like vue.js now? I hope, you not spend time in vain :)

I love it so far :) Thanks again for recommending it to me. Was very easy to get into, I had the basic version of ZeroTodos finished in the same evening I started learning Vue.js, The Vue guide is really easy to understand, well written.

I think the overall way it makes you structure your apps is also very neat. I've written ZeroTodos just as a general web app first using just Vue.js and then when that was done I added ZeroNet support (which was really simple at that point), which is completely separate, the Vue app doesn't know anything about ZeroNet.

There are just three callbacks you need to implement and register with the Vue app and  it could easily work with Firebase for example instead of ZeroNet, you don't have to rewrite any code. Really neat. And all of the functions are really short since Vue takes care of so much of the work for you that you really don't have much left to do :) The majority of the actual time spent I think went into the design, the CSS.

> [zozon](#comment_1_1QBLGLcgKfcpfLmiDYuDzUKVXFfmTAew55): excellent! well done! presentation, function, reasonable effectsgood example of what can be done with aid of some nice lib + of course mastery of putting it together.One possible idea - use of local storage of todo's one don't want to store in p2p 'cloud' and would use on one main device

Haven't figured out how to do that in Vue.js yet, but I'm sure I will :)

I'm currently converting ZeroQuotes to use Vue and that included converting all of the jQuery animations 1:1 to CSS3 animations (which was easier than I thought it would be) so that I can get rid of jQuery completely, which means I'm learning a lot more about animations right now anyhow.

Local storage of todo lists will be an option in a future update, haven't done that yet since localStorage is temporary storage in TorBrowser which means 40% of ZeroNet users couldn't use it (according to nofish about 40% of peers use Tor, including myself), but I think I can just write todos to a file that ZeroNet ignores and doesn't share with other users. I also plan to add public todo lists, so that I can share my ZeroQuotes and ZeroTodos todo lists so people can see what I'm working on, what bugs are known, etc.

> [muja](#comment_4_17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr)

It's done, took a bit longer than it would have because Firefox/TorBrowser is a bit more picky than Chrome when it comes to HTML5 drag and drop, but after a bit of googling I found the issue  (you need to define data to be transferred with the drag event even if you don't use the data, otherwise it won't work in Firefox, so I just transfer dummy text, literally the string "dummy").

You can drag both todo lists and tasks now to reorder them. Afterwards you need to click save (or just reload the page to cancel any reordering).

> [eventi](#comment_1_1DcDDitsjFJohvwonPmpibRChmA7uGxqL7): Polls have questions, questions have answers, answers have votes... How did you wind up doing it?

Best to take a look at the source code, it is very complicated. It's in ZeroPolls.coffee in YourZeroNetFolder/data/1K28kQFMquNzto2iQf4GGjr6oFUbC1NddE/js

Basically, answers are concatenated into a string so there is just one column in the database for all answers a question has, it's then split again in the code into multiple answers. For the votes, I had to do one SQL query for every poll displayed on the site to get all the votes for that poll, which is why this won't scale that well.

ZeroName works through a central server/node, you can make it work decentralized, there is a plugin for that in the plugins folder, but then you need to spend hours/days downloading the Namecoin blockchain. Blockchains are huge and cumbersome, sadly, don't scale well.

To the person who donated 0.2 BTC to me yesterday, you are nuts. Amazing and generous, but nuts. Thanks! That was a huge surprise.

> [odd](#comment_2_1EMpuiFM1NLZmAVyoAWnwi8VwiZVV4dcnN): It's possible to donate directly to a site address and the site owner can import the private key into bitcoin to receive the funds. It's probably a bit technical though for authors to go through the private key import process.

I thought about doing that at first, it doesn't seem to be that hard and maybe in the future ZeroNet can make that easier, in the interview with nofish in an article that was published shortly after the Torrentfreak article, I believe he said it's a possibility to build a Bitcoin wallet right into ZeroNet at some point to make this really simple. But I decided against it for now because then I'd have to give people a different address for every one of my ZeroNet sites and I wanted it to stay on my blog for now, not cluttering up the UI of the sites themselves, or putting it too much in the face of people.

I always feel bad about accepting donations. I shouldn't of course, like I said in the blog post hard work should be rewarded and getting into the habit of donating and being donated to might in the long term let us create a better internet without the privacy invasion and making people buy things they don't even want or need of advertising, but I still always feel a little bad about it, as if I'm telling people give me money or else you won't get anything from me, even though I would still make ZeroNet sites with no donations at all because I love doing it.

Also, security implications. If the ZeroNet dev ever fucks up and leaks the private keys of ZeroNet sites through a bug in ZeroNet, and that can always happen, we are all just human, someone could just empty your wallet. We have to keep in mind ZeroNet is only version 0.36 right now, we cannot expect perfect security this early, that would be putting an unfair amount of responsibility on poor nofish's head :) I know the Bitcoin devs had to deal with that when they kept telling people not to use it with real money yet because it's too early but nobody listened and of course people lost money.

> [basxto](#comment_1_1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k): You would need to discard the old votes, otherwise you could fake polls easily. This would need to save the voting time for every vote.

I might allow editing polls at some point, I've been thinking about that since I started working on ZeroPolls. My idea was that I'd add a cryptographic hash for every vote (calculated from a concatenation of the question and the answer) which makes sure the question and the answer voted on is still the same as of the time of voting, if not, it is not counted and you can vote again. Adding more options would work as long as they are added at the end, not somewhere in between, because I actually use the order of the answers as an index for the votes, saves space and is more efficient.

> [cadenoro](#comment_4_1vAdpJiyYEHcDZoJn93QcjzaFVKHHPg1F): A question, as I know very little about Dart. Based on your experience, why use Dart rather than Javascript?
> Is mise le meas.

The original goal for Dart as I understand it was to replace JavaScript which was quickly hacked together in a week or two, with a more well thought out language that fixes the issues with JavaScript, takes the best concepts from languages created over the years (mostly from a language called Smalltalk), and design it specifically to run as fast as possible inside of a virtual machine because it's getting harder and harder to make JavaScript faster in browsers, JavaScript just was not designed for what it's being used for today.

Microsoft and Mozilla (the two other big browser vendors) didn't want to cooperate with Google though despite them giving up control over Dart to a standards committee, understandable albeit unfortunate, so Google had to scrap the idea of Dart replacing JavaScript in web browsers and now just compiles it to JavaScript like most languages do, which means it's not faster anymore (in the browser) but still has all the other improvements.

As for why use Dart instead of JavaScript? They are very similar, not just the language but also the ecosystem. Instead of node.js to write server side and command line apps you've got the Dart VM, instead of npm for package management you've got pub. Instead of something like React Native for mobile development you've got Flutter. So Dart has all of that in an improved form and since it's made by one entity, Google, and everything was built to work together (for example when the team who made Flutter needed changes in Dart, the Dart team made those changes to the language), everything naturally does work much better together, Dart basically comes with batteries included it does everything you need out of the box. So if the choice is between Dart and JavaScript it's not really a hard choice, Dart wins hands down.

The more interesting question though is how Dart compares to other JavaScript competitors, there are probably a hundred now, and there I can't tell you much because I only really know CoffeeScript well. How does Dart compare to it? It's better IMHO, but CoffeeScript has a nicer syntax (Python like), but that depends on your taste/personal perference. And interacting with JavaScript is easier in CoffeeScript since it's not really a new language, it's just a new syntax. In Dart you have to add types for everything you want to use like in Microsoft's TypeScript. You can however automatically compile a TypeScript file for a JavaScript library if it exists, so you can profit from both the Dart and the TypeScript community's work.

So far I found working with Dart really nice, much nicer than CoffeeScript/JavaScript. The types really help a lot in figuring out how stuff works, and the IDE shows you not just what you did wrong but also often how to fix the problem, live while you write code so you don't even have to compile first. Flutter is amazing. Feels easier to use than even web development is but you get native mobile apps as a result (no web views, no virtual machine), I'll be continuing to use Dart for that reason alone.

AngularDart for web development I don't really like yet, I much prefer Vue.js (although components are a lot easier in AngularDart, you don't need to use something like webpack). Maybe it will grow on me. It seems to be a case of "it makes simple things hard and hard things simple". It definitely needs better documentation. Some of the code examples are outdated and don't work anymore (unless I did something wrong). I think Google is so focused on Flutter right now they forgot a bit about AngularDart because not many people use it outside of Google. Someone from Google is already working on an unofficial web version of Flutter though, so maybe I'll switch over to that when it's ready :) ZeroDart would work with it too, I developed it independently from AngularDart.

Out of the box, without AngularDart, you can use Dart for web development as well. It has a lot of nice additions that basically make it comparable to JavaScript + jQuery. So you don't have to use any framework at all with it if you don't want to, ZeroDart also works just fine that way.

The only real drawback that I can see to Dart right now is that the community is tiny so you have to figure out things on your own, you can't just look something up in a thousand places like you can do with JavaScript. That also makes it kind of exciting though! :D Forces you to learn. So probably not that great if you just need to get things done, quickly. Flutter might make it more popular in time.
